factoid: Narrator thought "Splendid! What a horse he will be!" with a smile.
Narrator held up his saber while his spurs jingled.
Narrator ran up the steps of the porch.
Landlord wore a waistcoat and a pointed cap and held a pitchfork.
Landlord was clearing manure from the cowhouse.
Landlord looked out.
Landlord's face brightened when he saw Rostóv.
Landlord said "Schön gut Morgen! Schön gut Morgen!" winking with a merry smile.
Landlord was evidently pleased to greet Rostóv.
Rostóv said "A very good morning! A very good morning!"
Rostóv said "Schon fleissig?" with a gay brotherly smile that did not leave his eager face.
Rostóv quoted "Hoch Oestreicher! Hoch Russen! Kaiser Alexander hoch!" words often repeated by the landlord.
Landlord laughed.
Landlord came out of the cowshed.
Landlord pulled off his cap.
Landlord waved his cap above his head and cried "Und die ganze Welt hoch!"
Rostóv waved his cap above his head like the German and cried laughing "Und vivat die ganze Welt!"
Neither the German nor Rostóv had any reason for rejoicing, but they looked at each other with joyful delight and brotherly love.
They wagged their heads in token of mutual affection.
They departed smiling.
Landlord returned to his cowshed.
Rostóv went to the cottage he occupied with Denísov.
Rostóv asked Lavrúshka, Denísov’s orderly, "What about your master?"
Lavrúshka answered that the master had not been in since the evening and must have been losing.
Lavrúshka said that if the master wins he comes back early to brag, but if he stays out till morning it means he’s lost and will come back in a rage.
Lavrúshka offered coffee.
Lavrúshka brought coffee ten minutes later.
Lavrúshka said "He's coming!"
Rostóv looked out of the window and saw Denísov coming home.
Denísov was a small man with a red face, sparkling black eyes, and black tousled mustache and hair.
Denísov wore an unfastened cloak, wide breeches hanging down in creases, and a crumpled shako on the back of his head.
Denísov came up to the porch gloomily, hanging his head.
Denísov shouted loudly and angrily "Lavwúska! take it off, blockhead!"
Lavrúshka replied that he was taking it off.
Denísov said "Ah, you’re up already."
Denísov entered the room.
Rostóv answered "Long ago, I have already been for the hay, and have seen Fräulein Mathilde."
Denísov said "We really! And I’ve been losing, brother. I lost yesterday like a damned fool!"
Denísov said "Such ill luck! Such ill luck. As soon as you left, it began and went on. Hullo there! Tea!"
Denísov puckered up his face though smiling, showing his short strong teeth, and began with stubby fingers of both hands to ruffle up his thick tangled black hair.
Denísov said "And what devil made me go to that wat?" (an officer nicknamed "the rat") he said, rubbing his forehead and whole face with both hands.
Denísov said "Just fancy, he didn’t let me win a single cahd, not one cahd."
Denísov took the lighted pipe that was offered to him.
Denísov gripped the pipe in his fist.
Denísov tapped the pipe on the floor.
Denísov made the sparks fly.
Denísov shouted while continuing to shout.
Denísov said "He lets one win the singles and collahs it as soon as one doubles it."
Denísov said "He gives the singles and snatches the doubles."
Denísov scattered the burning tobacco.
Denísov smashed the pipe.
Denísov threw the pipe away.
Denísov remained silent for a while.
Denísov looked cheerfully with his glittering black eyes at Rostóv.
